title: 103_s1013
content: The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" is cited in this section, which amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It addresses the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to address the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. This includes excluding the value of such land from the gross estate if the executor elects to do so. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude the value of land subject to a qualified conservation easement from the gross estate, with certain conditions. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude the value of land within 50 miles of a metropolitan area or national park from the gross estate, under certain conditions. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" excludes land within 50 miles of a park from the gross estate if owned by the decedent or family for 3 years and meets conservation contribution criteria. The qualified real property interest described in section 170(h)(2)(C) must be made by the decedent or a family member to qualify as a conservation contribution under section 170(h)(4)(A). The term "member of the decedent's family" is defined for this purpose. The estate tax imposes an additional tax on the first person disposing of land subject to a retained development right after a qualified conservation contribution is made. An additional estate tax is imposed on the first person disposing of property after the death of the decedent, based on the increase in estate tax liability if the value of the development right had been included in the gross estate. The estate tax is imposed on the person disposing of property after the decedent's death, based on the increase in tax liability if the development right value had been included in the gross estate. If only a portion of the property is disposed of, the person must pay a pro rata portion of the tax. The estate tax is imposed on the person disposing of property after the decedent's death, based on the increase in tax liability if the development right value had been included in the gross estate. Any tax imposed must be paid by April 15 of the following calendar year. The term 'development right' refers to the right. The term 'development right' in estate tax refers to the right to establish structures for commercial purposes or conduct farming activities. The election for land under a qualified conservation easement must be made on the tax return and is irrevocable once made, as prescribed by the Secretary. The executor must calculate and notify potential estate tax due after making an irrevocable election for a qualified conservation easement. A 'Notice of Potential Estate Tax Due' must be filed in public record places. The executor must calculate and notify potential estate tax due after electing a qualified conservation easement. The computation and filing must be done as prescribed by the Secretary. Carryover basis rules under the Internal Revenue Code are also amended. The executor must calculate and notify potential estate tax due after electing a qualified conservation easement. Amended provisions include adjusting the basis of property excluded from the gross estate of the decedent. These changes apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, including land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after that date. SEC. 3. Gift tax on land subject to a qualified conservation easement. Gift Tax With Respect to Land Subject to a Qualified Conservation Easement: Section 2503 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to exclude the transfer of land under a conservation easement from gift tax. The term 'land subject to a qualified conservation easement' has the same meaning as in section 2031(c), with adjustments for donor and transfer dates. If the donor retains development rights, an additional gift tax is imposed on the first person disposing of the property after the gift date. The additional gift tax is imposed on the person disposing of the property after the gift date, equal to the increase in gift tax liability if the development right had been treated as a gift. The term "development right" is defined as in section 2031(c)(3)(C), with rules of clauses (ii) and (iii) of paragraph (3)(B) and paragraph (5) of section 2031(c) applying, substituting "donor" for "executor". These amendments apply to gifts of land with conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992. SEC. 4. Qualified conservation contribution where surface and mineral rights are separated. Section 170(h)(5)(B)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a special rule for contributions of property with separated surface estate and mineral interests. The amendment applies to contributions where the probability of surface mining is negligible. The amendment made by this section applies to contributions made after December 31, 1992, in taxable years ending after that date. SEC. 5. Qualified conservation contribution is not a disposition. Qualified conservation contribution by gift or otherwise shall not be treated as a disposition for purposes of the alternative valuation method under section 2032A of the Internal Revenue Code. This exemption applies to qualified real property with a conservation easement. The amendment exempts land with a qualified conservation easement from being disqualified as qualified real property for alternative valuation under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment exempts land with a qualified conservation easement from being disqualified as qualified real property for alternative valuation under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, which include land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992.
